OK, so this is to do with the rate equations of
dynamic equilibria...

Something which anybody with a background in chemistry
will be familiar with...

Basically, if we have some process that changes
something from one state to another:

x -> y

Then the rate of that (in the most-common cases) is
going to be:

S_f = [x] * k_f

S = speed
_f being a suffix for "forwards"
[x] = the "activity" of x (which, if all x's are
available, just comes down to the number of x's)
k is a constant for this process (the "rate
constant").

((there's a whole load of assumptions I am making
here, like for example that the x's aren't queuing up
for a narrow doorway, but when we're talking about an
algorithm it is fairly easy to know that they do
apply))

OK, if the back process can also happen, then:

S_b = [y] * k_b

And the existance of those two processes is enough to
determine that there is an equilibrium position.  e.g.
any pot of mixed x and y will perform both these
processes and change the ration of x and y until it
reaches a point where S_f and S_b are equal.  This
point come when:

S_f = S_b

thus:

[x] * k_f = [y] * k_b

so:

[y]/[x] = k_f/k_b (= K)

This ratio, called "K" (note: CAPITALISED) is called
the "equilibrium constant" and is basically a measure
of how far "forwards" the system wants to be (e.g. a
system with K = 100 will come to rest with 100 times
more Y than x).

--

OK, so back to NEAT.

We have the following processes (I'm using <-> to show
that a process goes both ways):

g0 <-> g1 <-> g2 <-> g3 <-> g4 <-> ...

Where g1 is a genome with 1 gene, g2 is a genome with
2 genes, etc...

So the question is, what are the rate constants for
this, and they are very simple, for this:

g0 <-> g1

k_f = the "add" mutation rate (m_a)
k_b = the "del" mutation rate (m_d)

So this part of the system will come to rest with:

K_0_1 = g1/g0 = m_a/m_d

And if we set m_a = m_d (just for illustration) that
will be 50:50...

--

Looking at the next link in the chain:

g1 <-> g2

k_f = m_a, but,
b_f = 2 * m_d

Why is that?  Because this genome has _two_ genes to
lose, and each gene has a m_d chance of being lost
(yes, there is some extra complexity here where it
could lose two genes in one step and gecome a g0, but
in practise the analysis doesn't change if you ignore
that -- because it is no different in its consequences
than if that change happened in two steps).

So for this step in the chain:

K_1_2 = g2/g1 = m_a/(2 * m_d)

And that's going to be 66:33

--

So you can see the general situation, the strength of
the reverse process gets stronger and stronger as you
move to larger and larger genomes, so that the
quilibrium position of between each g(n) and g(n + 1)
gets further towards the smaller end.

I this case, I set the two probabilities equal, so the
best the two rates can do is be equal, and that
happens between g0 and g1.  However, if I had set m_d
< m_a, then the balance point would have been roughly
at g(m_a/m_d)...

--

All of this is assuming that you apply a separate
chance for gene deletion to each gene, rather than
applying a flat rate to the whole genome and then just
picking which gene to delete, but in that latter case,
you have a different sort of mechanism, and basically
only have the choice of:

m_a < m_d : expected size zero
m_a = m_d : no expected size, just a random walk over
all natural numbers
m_a > m_d : expected size infinity (eventually :)

--

Obviously all that is in the absence of selection. 
Selection pushes those equilibria around with great
ease (which is why my current run, with an expected
size of two, is currently hovering around an average
size of 100...

--

Personally, I'm beginning to think that the
relationship between how you run delete probability
(e.g. per gene or per genome) and how you handle
unmatched genes during cross over are pretty crucial
for the control of genome size.  Unless you do both
right, the ratio of m_a and m_d give far less control
over the rate of bloat than you would ever expect...

This is all assuming you have deletion as a mutation,
if you do it another way then obviously there is no
bassis for comparison.
